abstract: There seems to be a growing consensus that Washington has two options if it wants to end the credit freeze and restore confidence in our banking system. One is to, in effect, nationalize the major banks, which would be hugely expensive and would undermine our free-market system. The other is the “bad bank” solution, under which the government would print enormous amounts of money to buy all these banks’ “toxic” assets and to put them into a huge new financial institution that would operate under federal control and sell them off over time.

lead_paragraph: Barclays stock fell in trading in London after Moody’s Investors Service cut the bank’s long-term debt rating by two levels, citing the possibility of more credit write-downs and bad loans. Moody’s lowered the rating to Aa3, its fourth-highest grade, the firm said. The outlook was “stable,” Moody’s said, and it reduced the financial-strength rating one level. Barclays fell 11 percent, to 94.9 pence. Barclays said it wrote off about £8 billion ($11.5 billion) of credit assets in 2008.

lead_paragraph: Luxury home prices in London fell 3.7 percent in a month as would-be buyers struggled in January to secure mortgages from banks hurt by the financial crisis. In the last 12 months, the average price of homes that cost more than £1 million ($1.4 million) has slumped 21 percent, according to the real estate firm Knight Frank. House prices across Britain fell 1.3 percent in January from the previous month and about 17 percent on an annual basis, said Nationwide Building Society.

The extensions found on Artzilla won’t help you organize bookmarks or add nifty features. abstract: Why isn’t money for mass transit — which would stimulate the economy and do some long-term good — in the stimulus bill? Two experts offer answers.
snippet: Why isn’t money for mass transit — which would stimulate the economy and do some long-term good — in the stimulus bill? Two experts offer answers.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, money for mass-transit agencies seems to be a fine form of stimulus. Many local agencies are now facing budget shortfalls, leading them to raise fares, cut services and lay off workers. If the federal government sent money to these agencies, it would prevent some job cuts — serving as a quick form of stimulus, since a job not lost is just as good as one created. Money for mass transit would also make it easier for low-income workers, who are so far bearing the brunt of the recession, to get to their jobs or to search for new ones.

headline.main: Buses, Trains and Stimulus

abstract: Some ideas about how to price toxic assets and how to make a public-private partnership work on a “bad bank.”
snippet: Some ideas about how to price toxic assets and how to make a public-private partnership work on a “bad bank.”
lead_paragraph: In my column this week, I come out solidly in favor of nationalizing insolvent banks. It took me a while to get there; longer than it should have, really. Others, like Nouriel Roubini, who wrote an article in The Washington Post making the case for nationalization recently, Paul Krugman of The Times and other influential academics, have been way ahead in seeing the obviousness of this solution. Really, it’s pretty simple. If the government is going to be capitalizing the banks, it really needs to own the common equity — or warrants that can be converted to common. It is hard to understand why the government has been so concerned about protecting the banks’ shareholders and unsecured bondholders.

headline.main: A Few New Ideas to Help Tim Geithner

lead_paragraph: Foster’s Group, Australia’s biggest brewer, will retain its global wine business because the worldwide economic recession is making it difficult to find a buyer. Instead, the company will sell 36 vineyards and split its sales teams along beer and wine lines as it seeks to save 100 million Australian dollars annually, Foster’s said in a statement. The global economic slump, weak American demand and a glut of competing wine assets seeking buyers led Ian Johnston, the chief executive of Foster’s, to retain the division, which sells the brands Penfolds, Rosemount and Lindemans. Foster’s is based in Melbourne.

headline.main: Foster’s Decides to Keep Wine Business After All

The 425 hourly workers and 350 salaried employees will be let go by May, according a statement from David Barnas, a Delphi spokesman. The operation is under contract to be sold to Platinum Equity.

abstract: Crude oil traded near $37 a barrel in New York on speculation a deepening recession in Europe and Asia will stifle demand for energy and fuel.
snippet: Crude oil traded near $37 a barrel in New York on speculation a deepening recession in Europe and Asia will stifle demand for energy and fuel.
lead_paragraph: Crude oil traded near $37 a barrel in New York on speculation a deepening recession in Europe and Asia will stifle demand for energy and fuel. Brent crude, a benchmark for European, Africa and Russian grades, fell to a three-week low after British bank stocks dropped and the Bank of England said the economy’s first quarter contraction might match last quarter’s decline of 1.5 percent. Japan, the world’s third-largest oil consumer, said that its economy contracted the most since 1974 in the fourth quarter. “The market data from the U.S. and the other major economies is not painting a picture of an imminent recovery,” said Toby Hassall, research analyst at Commodity Warrants Australia in Sydney. “The Japanese data was pretty bad.” Crude oil for March delivery traded at $36.85 a barrel, down 68 cents from the Friday close, in electronic trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange at 10:38 a.m. in Sydney. Floor trading was closed for the Presidents’ Day holiday, so Monday’s transactions will be booked for settlement on Tuesday.

headline.main: Crude Oil Prices Fall Below $37 a Barrel
headline.print_headline: Crude Oil Prices Fall Below $37 a Barrel

A Lenovo spokeswoman in São Paulo declined to comment.

abstract: The combination of Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation is a relative rarity these days. It is a merger of equals. Merger of equals are a means for companies to combine with no designated “acquirer.” Instead, the companies publicly proclaim that this is a strategic combination without the need for such formalities. In pursuit of this equality, the board of directors of the combined company is split equally between directors from each company. There is also typically a brokered power-sharing arrangement among the chief executives. The shareholders from each company retain ownership in the combined entity since these deals are structured as stock-for-stock tax-free exchanges.
lead_paragraph: The combination of Ticketmaster Entertainment and Live Nation is a relative rarity these days. It is a merger of equals. Merger of equals are a means for companies to combine with no designated “acquirer.” Instead, the companies publicly proclaim that this is a strategic combination without the need for such formalities. In pursuit of this equality, the board of directors of the combined company is split equally between directors from each company. There is also typically a brokered power-sharing arrangement among the chief executives. The shareholders from each company retain ownership in the combined entity since these deals are structured as stock-for-stock tax-free exchanges.

headline.main: The Return of the Merger of Equals

In my youth, I adored The Daughter of Time by Josephine TEY. (The bed-ridden protagonist tries to solve the age-old mystery of whether Richard III murdered the princes in the tower.) “Slowing in music” is either RALL or RIT, and only one of those fit. “Hyphenated IDs” are SSNS. abstract: Pfizer, the world’s biggest drug maker, is significantly reducing the value of the severance packages for top managers in a nod to public pressure to reduce executive pay.
snippet: Pfizer, the world’s biggest drug maker, is significantly reducing the value of the severance packages for top managers in a nod to public pressure to reduce executive pay.
lead_paragraph: Pfizer, the world’s biggest drug maker, is significantly reducing the value of the severance packages for top managers in a nod to public pressure to reduce executive pay. The new executive severance plan took effect Monday, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Pfizer’s new plan would provide top officers terminated without cause with benefits including a severance payment equaling one to two times the total of their annual base salary and target bonus. That still amounts to at least a few million dollars for some officers and nearly $10 million for the chief executive, Jeffrey B. Kindler.

headline.main: Pfizer Reduces Executive Severance Pay
headline.print_headline: Pfizer Reduces Executive Severance Pay

abstract: The mining giant Anglo American said that it would suspend dividend payments for 2008 and cut 19,000 jobs, a tenth of its work force.
snippet: The mining giant Anglo American said that it would suspend dividend payments for 2008 and cut 19,000 jobs, a tenth of its work force.
lead_paragraph: The mining giant Anglo American said that it would suspend dividend payments for 2008 and cut 19,000 jobs, a tenth of its work force. The company blamed shrinking auto production, reduced construction projects in emerging economies and a sharp fall in commodity prices. “The breadth and severity of the global economic downturn and its impact on growth rates in key sectors and economies are difficult to overstate,” the chief executive, Cynthia Carroll, said in a statement. Anglo American mines minerals including platinum, iron ore, copper and diamonds. It is the world’s fourth-largest diversified mining company, with operations centered in southern Africa.

headline.main: Mining Company to Cut 19,000 Jobs
headline.print_headline: Mining Company To Cut 19,000 Jobs

abstract: The National Beef Packing Company, the fourth-largest United States beef processor, said that its sale to a Brazilian beef producer, JBS, had been dropped.
snippet: The National Beef Packing Company, the fourth-largest United States beef processor, said that its sale to a Brazilian beef producer, JBS, had been dropped.
lead_paragraph: A beef industry buyout that regulators were trying to block on antitrust grounds has been called off. The National Beef Packing Company, the fourth-largest United States beef processor, said that its sale to a Brazilian beef producer, JBS, had been dropped. JBS said last March that it would acquire National Beef, based in Kansas City, Mo., in a $560 million stock-and-cash transaction. In October, the Justice Department filed a lawsuit to block the deal, saying it could push up costs for consumers and drive down prices paid to ranchers and feedlots.

headline.main: Buyout of Meatpacker Is Dropped
headline.print_headline: Buyout Of Meatpacker Is Dropped

lead_paragraph: The Kirin Holdings Company of Japan plans to take a 43 percent stake in the San Miguel Corporation’s Philippine beer unit, San Miguel Brewery. Kirin will pay 58.9 billion pesos ($1.22 billion), partly financed by the sale of its holding in the brewery’s parent, the Japanese company said. San Miguel Brewery was spun off last May as the parent company diversified into energy and mining.

headline.main: Kirin to Buy Stake in Philippine Brewer

abstract: Enel, Italy’s biggest utility, agreed to buy a 25.01 percent stake in Endesa from Acciona.
snippet: Enel, Italy’s biggest utility, agreed to buy a 25.01 percent stake in Endesa from Acciona.
lead_paragraph: Enel, Italy’s biggest utility, agreed to buy a 25.01 percent stake in Endesa from Acciona for 11.1 billion euros ($14.2 billion), gaining full control of Spain’s largest hydropower producer. The purchase will include the transfer of 2.9 billion euros’ worth of Endesa’s renewable energy assets to Acciona, Enel said in an e-mailed statement. Acciona, a Madrid-based builder, will receive 9.6 billion euros from Enel, with the remaining 1.5 billion euros being paid through an early dividend by Endesa. Acciona and Enel bought the Spanish utility for 42.5 billion euros in October 2007.

headline.main: Italian Utility Buys Out Spanish Partner in Venture

abstract: Solve this Tuesday puzzle whenever your heart desires.
snippet: Solve this Tuesday puzzle whenever your heart desires.
lead_paragraph: Did you notice that this puzzle isn’t square? It has 15 rows, but it had to go to 16 columns to fit the central theme answer. That alone probably makes it harder to fit into the newspaper space, but on top of that, it also has 81 “words” or answers, and that’s a lot. Only six daily puzzles in my database have more. I’m guessing all that combines to explain why most of the clues are short. That count of 81 words is not only large, but it’s also unusual because it’s an odd number. If you like math, you might enjoy coming up with a proof of why standard puzzles have even word counts.

headline.main: Eat Humble Pie

abstract: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about the relationship of the financier Robert Allen Stanford to the Caribbean island of Antigua misstated the year when he started his first offshore bank, on Montserrat. It was 1986, not 1996. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of a cricket stadium built by Mr. Stanford. The stadium, on Mr. Stanford’s property, is used for short matches sponsored by the Stanford International Bank; it is not the national stadium. (The national cricket stadium is the Sir Vivian Richards Stadium.).

abstract: Two banks were seized including the Heritage Community Bank of Glenwood, Ill., and Security Savings Bank of Henderson, Nev.
snippet: Two banks were seized including the Heritage Community Bank of Glenwood, Ill., and Security Savings Bank of Henderson, Nev.
lead_paragraph: Two banks, Heritage Community Bank of Glenwood, Ill., and Security Savings Bank of Henderson, Nev., were seized by regulators, bringing the total number of United States banks shut this year to 16. Heritage, with $232.9 million in assets and deposits of $218.6 million, was shut by the Illinois Department of Financial Professional Regulation, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was named receiver. MB Financial Bank of Chicago will assume deposits. The failed bank’s four offices will open Saturday as branches of MB Financial.

headline.main: Banks Seized by Regulators, Bringing 2009 Total to 16

Conversations begin effortlessly. What did you think of Puzzle 2? Did you see how quickly Tyler finished? What did you get for 42 Across? Oh, I can’t believe I missed that!
